prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This goal covers our uniform mapping of the CO(3-2) line and the 13CO(3-2) lines. Like our other observations, we target 1 K rms in a 1 km/s channel. This furnishes the sensitivity we need to reach our science goals while preserving sufficient spectral resolution to study the kinematics of a spiral density wave in detail. We have JCMT CO(3-2) data, which we have used to confirm our sensitivity estimates. However, we are unable to reach good overlapping spatial coverage with the JCMT's 14-m dish with ALMA. Since the science case requires robust flux measurements over the entire spiral arm (25" spatial scales), we require ACA/TP observations for these Band 7 data in addition to the 12-m observations.
We configure the correlator to observe the CO(3-2) line as the primary line but also CS(7-6) and 13CO(3-2) as secondary lines. We note that we smoothed data from a few star forming regions in the JCMT/Gould Belt Legacy survey to match the expected resolution of the ALMA data. Based on this small sample, we should see several detections of the 13CO(3-2) and possibly CS(7-6) in our sample (T_r = 5 K).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(1-0) Map
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a matched sensitivity map of the CO(1-0) emission for combination with the Nobeyama 45-m map of the galaxy in the same tracer.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
CO(1-0): These data provide the primary constraint on low volume density / low column density CO emitting gas, often called the chaff. As with all our goals, we target a 1 K rms in a 1 km/s channel. Based on PDR modelling, this will afford us clear detections of the CO emission down the edges of molecular clouds where A_V ~ 1 mag and the CO will be dissociated. Unlike the other science goals, we target a 1"=4 pc resolution for two reasons. First, this will allow matching and combination with the Nobeyama 45-m data, since too few baselines overlapped with the < 30-m spacings that the Nobeyama data provide information on. Second, the surface brightness sensitivity of the 12-m array is adversely affected at the primary resolution of the survey (0.5") and completing a full suite of matched resolution maps will be left to the future. This correspondingly poorer linear resolution will not affect our goals significantly since the ground-state CO emission is found in diffuse gas with larger characteristic scales than the higher excitation condition lines. Furthermore, the core mapping area is somewhat extended in the CO(1-0) data to better balance the overhead vs. integration time balance, while exploring a larger portion of the spiral arm.
We have configured the correlator to observe the CO(1-0) line and other spectral windows include the CN radicals and wide-band windows targeting the millimeter continuum. We have selected a spectral resolution that keeps at least 1 km/s resolution in the resulting data for evaluating the kinematic offsets between different parts of the spectral lines.

CO(2-1): The pair of science goals for the CO(2-1) observations provides good sensitivity data to match existing IRAM 30-m observations of the CO(2-1) line for use as short spacing and total power. The nominal map resolution of 0.5" requires an extended configuration with too little coverage near 15 klambda where the 30-m data become sensitive. To provide the missing coverage, we submit a second short science goal with a nominal resolution of 1.5" which provides ample coverage in the overlap annulus. We adopt the same sensitivity in both science goal to match noise levels in all regions of the uv-plane. Like our other observations, we target 1 K rms in a 1 km/s channel. This furnishes the sensitivity we need to reach our science goals while preserving sufficient spectral resolution to study the kinematics of a spiral density wave in detail. We have verified with the ALMA simulator that these short spacing data with the 12-m array are needed for good sampling down to 15 klambda.
We have configured the correlator to observe the (2-1) lines of 12CO, 13CO, C18O as our primary lines. We configure the other two spectral windows in high resolution continuum mode in hopes of serendipitously detecting other spectral lines. We will utilize the continuum data in studies of the dusty ISM in M33.

CO(2-1): The pair of science goals for the CO(2-1) observations provides good sensitivity data to match existing IRAM 30-m observations of the CO(2-1) line for use as short spacing and total power. The nominal map resolution of 0.5" requires an extended configuration with too little coverage near 15 klambda where the 30-m data become sensitive. To provide the missing coverage, we submit a second short science goal with a nominal resolution of 1.5" which provides ample coverage in the overlap annulus. We adopt the same sensitivity in both science goal to match noise levels in all regions of the uv-plane. Like our other observations, we target 1 K rms in a 1 km/s channel. This furnishes the sensitivity we need to reach our science goals while preserving sufficient spectral resolution to study the kinematics of a spiral density wave in detail. We have verified with the ALMA simulator that these short spacing data with the 12-m array are needed for good sampling down to 15 klambda.
We have configured the correlator to observe the (2-1) lines of 12CO, 13CO, C18O as our primary lines. We configure the other two spectral windows in high resolution continuum mode in hopes of serendipitously detecting other spectral lines. We will utilize the continuum data in studies of the dusty ISM in M33.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Abstract: When present, spiral structure hosts most of the star formation in disk galaxies. Despite its ubiquity, we know relatively little about the details of star formation in spiral arms. For example, do spiral arms form molecular clouds or merely collect and excite existing cloud? ALMA provides a new approach to studying spiral structure. We propose the first high-resolution (0.5"=2 pc), top-down map of molecular clouds in a spiral arm of any galaxy. We target the southern spiral arm of the galaxy M33, which provides the ONLY low-inclination view of a nearby (< 1 Mpc) galactic disk. Using the J=(1-0), (2-1) and (3-2) 12CO transitions coupled with their rarer isotopologues, we will obtain a detailed map of the physical conditions in molecular clouds as they pass through the spiral arm. This proposal leverages a suite of in-hand data, including short spacing and total power constraints on two of our key tracers. With these data, we will (1) provide the first map of molecular gas excitation through a spiral arm, (2) track the formation of dense gas clumps from a completely new perspective and (3) critically test theories of spiral structure.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
